title: German submarine U-306
text:
German submarine "U-306" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. The submarine was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 16 September 1941 at the "<a href="Flender%20Werke">Flender Werke</a>" yard at <a href="L%C3%BCbeck">Lübeck</a> as yard number 306, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 29 August 1942 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 21 October under the command of "<a href="Oberleutnant">Oberleutnant</a>" Claus von Trotha.
During her career, the U-boat sailed on five combat patrols, sinking one ship and damaging two others, before she was sunk on 31 October 1943 in mid-Atlantic, northwest of the <a href="Azores">Azores</a> by British warships.
She was a member of three <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>s.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-306" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Garbe%2C%20Lahmeyer%20%26amp%3B%20Co.">Garbe, Lahmeyer & Co.</a> RP 137/c <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-306" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and two twin <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> <a href="anti-aircraft%20gun">anti-aircraft gun</a>s. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
The boat's service life began with training with the <a href="8th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">8th U-boat Flotilla</a> on 21 October 1942. She was then transferred to the <a href="1st%20U-boat%20Flotilla">1st flotilla</a> for operations on 1 March 1943.
First patrol.
The submarine's first patrol began with her departure from <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> on 25 February 1943. On 22 April she sank the "Amerika" south of <a href="Cape%20Farewell%2C%20Greenland">Cape Farewell, Greenland</a>. The next day she damaged the "Silvermaple". She arrived in <a href="Brest%2C%20France">Brest</a> in occupied France, on 9 May.
Second and third patrols.
"U-306"s second foray was relatively uneventful; starting in Brest, it took her as far south as <a href="Guinea-Bissau">Guinea-Bissau</a>. Off <a href="the%20Gambia">the Gambia</a>, she damaged the "Kaipara" on 16 July 1943. The boat then docked in <a href="Lorient">Lorient</a> on 11 August.
Her third sortie was rather brief, lasting between 23 and 24 September 1943.
Fourth patrol.
On her fourth patrol, she sailed along the French Atlantic coast toward <a href="St.%20Nazaire">St. Nazaire</a>.
Fifth patrol and loss.
The boat was sunk northwest of the Azores by <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a>s dropped from the British destroyer and the corvette on 31 October 1943.
Fifty-one men died; there were no survivors.
